Award.AwardTitle: Novel transport phenomena in two-dimensional crystals beyond graphene
Award.AbstractNarration:
Bon-Technical Abstract:
Semiconductors have revolutionized out lives. Recently new types of semiconductors, such as single atomic layers of transition metal dichalcogenides and black phosphorus, have become available. This project studies several types of novel transport phenomena in these materials. These transport phenomena, such as collision-free ballistic transport and coherent plasma oscillation, play important roles in nanoscale electronic devices. This project provides fundamental information about these transport phenomena, and reveals rich physics involved in nonequilibrium transport in solids. Furthermore, the studies of several novel spin transport phenomena provide information for application of these materials in spin-based electronics. This project achieves broader impacts by training graduate and undergraduate students, involving K-12 teachers, broadening participation of underrepresented groups, and enhancing research infrastructure on nanotechnology and renewable energy technology.

Technical Abstract:
The scientific problem studied in this project is nonequilibrium ballistic charge and spin transport in two-dimensional crystals, including transition metal dichalcogenides and phosphorene. The methods and approaches of this project are based on three ultrafast laser techniques: a quantum interference and control technique that can instantaneously inject ballistic charge and spin currents, a differential pump-probe technique that can resolve sub-nanometer motion of electrons, and a second-harmonic generation technique for ultrafast and direct detection of the velocity of electrons. The goals of this project are to understand and control several novel transport phenomena in two-dimensional crystals, such as coherence plasma oscillation, ballistic charge transport, ballistic pure spin transport, spin Hall effect, spin-polarized charge transport, and spin Gunn effect.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The discovery of graphene, a single layer of carbon atoms forming a honeycomb lattice, has created an exponentially growing interest in two-dimensional (2D) materials, such as single atomic layers of transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs), transition metal oxides, hexagonal boron nitride, phosphorene, silicine, and germanene. So far, about 100 types of 2D materials have been produced, with much more yet to be discovered. These ultrathin materials (1 nm or thinner) possess many unique features that make them attractive to both scientific research and industrial applications. In particular, their novel electronic and optical properties are attractive for the next-generation electronic and optoelectronic technologies, such as photodetector, photovoltaic, transistor, and memory devices.

For developing these electronic and optoelectronic applications, it is important to understand and control electron transport inside and between 2D semiconductors. In this project, we used ultrafast laser techniques to study both the in-plane transport of electrons in various 2D semiconductors and the interlayer transport of electrons between 2D semiconductors in heterostructures. For in-plane transport, we studied diffusion of photoexcited electrons in several new 2D semiconductors and heterostructures. We also time-resolved electron transport across junctions inside a monolayer semiconductor. These result help understand mechanisms of in-plane electron transport in 2D materials and their lateral junctions, which are important for developing planar 2D optoelectronic devices. On interlayer electron transport, we achieved highly efficient and coherent electron transport in heterostructures formed by three different TMD monolayers, which suggests the feasibility of constructing multilayer van der Waals materials with superior vertical transport performance; We demonstrated that by controlling the interlayer electron transport, the photocarrier lifetime in graphene can be improved by two orders of magnitude. Since the photocarrier lifetime is directly related to the efficiency of photovoltaic and the sensitivity of the photodetection devices, this discovery illustrates the effectiveness of band-alignment engineering to improve material performance for such applications; We time-resolved electron transport between two TMD monolayers of the same type, which revealed important information on the physical mechanisms of  electron interlayer transport; We demonstrated the first TMD heterostructure with a type-I band alignment, which can be used as building blocks for van der Waals multilayers with complex band alignments; We achieved good electron transport performance between amorphous and crystalline 2D materials, which expanded the 2D material library to amorphous form. Overall, these findings on novel transport phenomena in 2D materials provide much needed knowledge for developing electronic and optoelectronic technology based on 2D materials.

These research results have broader impacts of advancing technology that will benefit the society. This project also contributed to public scientific literacy and public engagement in science and technology by offering public presentations and lab tours and by developing public-accessible materials to promote awareness of the latest scientific research through media. Research results were used as teaching materials, demonstrations, and examples in undergraduate courses. Human resource development achieved in this project includes training of five graduate students (with 4 graduated with PhDs), one undergraduate, and one high-school student. The project improved participation of underrepresented minorities and women in STEM fields.
